There are only two possibilities for this stupid reaction, the Secretary of Defense does not trust the troops the administration sends out to fight and die, or he is afraid that an Afghan "ally" will take a weapon away from a Marine and go on killing spree. Either way it's an action that says more about this the true situation and thought patterns of this administration than anything else.

Mr. Panetta is the SecDef, not the president, he is replaceable. If, God forbid, he is killed, we'll just go on. He has done more damage to morale - a key element in any military campaign - than he knows.

It's $20 worth of fun, and you occasionally hit it "big", which means lugging around a s*load of nickels and trying like mad to lose those, too.

So, if you think you can win, think of it this way:

-Odds in Mega are 1:175,000,000.
-Width of a small walnut shell: 1 inch.
-Line up 175,000,000 walnut shells from Washington DC to Los Angeles (2686mi x 5280ft/mi x 12 inches)
-Have someone put the magic bean under one of those shells.
-Now you get to pick the shell somewhere in between DC and LA with the magic bean under it.
-Oh, you're in an office pool? Fine. Pick 100 shells.

Sure someone's gonna win, but think about those walnut shells next time you're paying the idiot tax as the gas station.

But then why is the name of the Spanish city, Jerez (de la Frontera) pronounced "hereth"?

. . .because in Castillian pronunciation, the "z" has a "th" sound, as does a c followed by an i. Therefore, Jerez is "Jereth," Valencia is "Balenthia."

Vale? Bueno.

Because Castillian Spanish (what is spoken in central Spain, as opposed to Latin America) has a lisp, so an ending S is pronounced TH. And all Js in Spanish, except for in a few regional dialects) are pronounced like an English H.

Both Lopez (Spanish) and Lopes (Portuguese) are pronounced the same way and the final e is pronounced. The stress is on Lo and not on pez/pes. It is the "american" pronunciation that stresses ez/es. I've always found this weird, but the same thing happens with the (italian) word latte (stress on la, not on final e).
So, I'd say either try to say it right or don't bother; especially since there is no difference between (Lopez and Lopes). In case you are wondering, I am Brazilian, married with an Argentine.
